Suggested Reading: The Night Circus

Posted on May 20, 2013 by

Where do I start?  I absolutely love this book.  It’s been out a while, and I hear they’re doing a movie (JOY!).  But if you haven’t read it yet, then go and get a copy right now!  In my opinion, Erin Morgenstern is one of the very best new authors we have.

From the official site : “The circus arrives without warning. No announcements precede it. It is simply there, when yesterday it was not. Within the black-and-white striped canvas tents is an utterly unique experience full of breathtaking amazements. It is called Le Cirque des Rêves, and it is only open at night.”

I’m getting chills all over again, just thinking about the subtlety, grace, and stunning beauty of this book.   There’s magicians and real magic, visual perfection, fascinating characters (the clock maker is my favorite, of course), midnight dinner parties, wonderful locations, intrigue, tarot, murder, gorgeous cafes — and all of it in black and white and red.

Seriously, go read it now!

Or, at least play the browser game.

Posted in Suggested Reading Tagged Clockwork Twist, Emily Thompson, Erin Morgenstern, magician, neo-Victorian, steampunk, The Night Circus, victoriana Leave a comment

Twist is going to Clockwork Alchemy 2013!

Posted on April 22, 2013 by

It’s official now.  After much deliberation and form-filling, Twist’s radiant, erudite (and ever so humble) author will be presenting at this year’s Clockwork Alchemy steampunk convention in San Jose, Ca, May 24th – 27th!

If you’re in the San Jose area and like a bit of steampunk, come in for the day!  There’ll be musical and special guests, lots of things to buy with gears glued on, weirdos–erm…  I mean, wonderfully attired individuals, and a library of all things steampunk with loads of authors and book signings!

I’ll be there as well, signing books and selling swag.  I also want to post lots of photos with my gorgeous readers on this site, so if you come to the con be sure to look for me in the author section and say hi!  I hope to see you there.

Posted in Twisty things Tagged clockwork alchemy, Clockwork Twist, CWTwist, Emily Thompson, neo-Victorian, steampunk, victoriana Leave a comment

Suggested Reading: Maids of Misfortune

Posted on April 15, 2013 by

I’ve recently run across a wonderful little treat!  Maids of Misfortune is a lovely historical mystery set in my (nearly) home town of San Francisco.  It was written by a fellow indie author name M. Louisa Locke.  Here’s part of the description on her site.

“It’s the summer of 1879, and Annie Fuller, a young San Francisco widow, is in trouble. Annie’s husband squandered her fortune before committing suicide five years earlier, and one of his creditors is now threatening to take the boardinghouse she owns to pay off a debt.”

On top of that, Annie is one of San Francisco’s most exclusive clairvoyants!  Then, one of her clients turns up murdered!  How devilishly fantastic!  If you like Steampunk, Neo-Victorian, or Historical Fiction, or are looking for work by the dashing rouges of the publishing industry, you’ll certainly enjoy this book.  Check out M. Louisa Locke’s site, and get the Kindle sample of her novel for free, today!

Posted in Suggested Reading Tagged Clockwork Twist, Emily Thompson, M. Louisa Locke, Maids of Misfortune, neo-Victorian, steampunk, victoriana Leave a comment

Offshore drilling started in the Caspian Sea?

Posted on April 8, 2013 by

I think it’s safe to say that the workhorse of industry in the 1870s was coal.  They used it for all those lovely steam engines, to warm their homes, and of course for the occasional charcoal drawings.  But did you know that 60 years before Henry Ford was even born, a guy named Gasimbey Mansurbeyov was drilling for oil, offshore in the Caspian Sea?  They weren’t using oil for gasoline, but Baku, the city at the heart of the oil business in Azerbaijan, was already getting rich off the profits of oil.  Go figure.

Here’s some nice photos of Baku.  It’s a neat looking city. Continue reading →

Posted on April 1, 2013 by

In honor of April Fools, here’s a bit of fun!  Browsing a bit too much, I came across some funny old photos that really caught my eye.  Victoriana has so many sides to it, it’s sometimes easy to forget a few.  First off, not sure if it’s really Victorian or Edwardian, but here’s a “Victorian photobomb” I found on Memebase.

This girl has her own brand of swag.  I bet she could tell you some stories.  And I think the pearls set off the jungle scene fantastically, don’t you?

Last but surely not least, Victorian Surrealism!!  Oh boy, oh boy!  The internet loves me.  It gives me all the nicest thing!  All I can say is that I want more.  Click the image to see other wonderful bits of bizarre by the fantastic artist,  Jeffrey Michael Harp.

“My Watch” by Mark Twain

Posted on March 25, 2013 by

Time for something truly awesome.  This is a wonderful little tale by the great Mark Twain.  (Thanks to Flamingo Teal, for the tip!)   The moment I read this, I simply had to share it!  I’ve so been there, man…

My Watch: An Instructive Little Tale

Written in 1870 by Mark Twain (1835-1910)

This version originally published in 2005 by Infomotions, Inc. It was derived from the Internet Wiretap Edition of My Watch by Mark Twain From “Sketches New and Old”, Copyright 1903, Samuel Clemens. It was placed in the Public Domain (June 1993, #16). (Written about 1870.) This document is distributed under the GNU Public License.

    My beautiful new watch had run eighteen months without losing or gaining, and without breaking any part of its machinery or stopping. I had come to believe it infallible in its judgments about the time of day, and to consider its constitution and its anatomy imperishable. But at last, one night, I let it run down. Continue reading →

What is Steampunk???

Posted on February 18, 2013 by

I realize that this isn’t the most well known Sci-Fi sub genre in the world, so here’s a crash course in Steampunk, Victoriana, and Neo-Victorian.

Steampunk is speculative fiction, usually set between 1850 and 1900, and is mostly set in either London or the Old West.  It’s also sometimes set in a purely fictional world that is full of Victorian era details.  Jules Verne is also aprimary source for many Steampunk enthusiasts.  It’s both fantasy and Sci-fi, focusing on various occult and magical themes, mixed with misplaced technology and lots of goggles, steam power, airships, and clockwork. Continue reading →
